• The study examines the luminosity profiles of young massive star clusters, specifically m82-f, ngc 1569-a, and ngc 1705-1, to determine if they are in dynamical equilibrium after gas expulsion.
• Observations and @xmath0-body simulations indicate that these clusters display excess light at large radii, suggesting they are not in virial equilibrium due to rapid gas loss.
• The simulations show that clusters with a star formation efficiency of 40-50% best reproduce the observed profiles, indicating a significant effect of gas expulsion on cluster evolution.
• The study supports the hypothesis of "infant mortality," where young clusters are rapidly dissolved due to gas expulsion, leading to a discrepancy in the observed versus expected number of young clusters.
• The excess light at large radii in the observed profiles is a signature of violent relaxation, suggesting that the clusters are still influenced by the initial gas expulsion event.
• The study challenges previous claims of non-standard initial mass functions (IMFs) for young star clusters, as they are likely not in virial equilibrium when observed.
• The findings imply that the observed mass function of clusters may be affected by both the loss of low-mass stars (infant weight-loss) and the dissolution of young clusters (infant mortality).
• The study suggests that the star formation efficiency within clusters needs to be accounted for when relating the observed mass function to the birth mass function.
• The research provides evidence that gas expulsion is a critical phase in the evolution of young star clusters, affecting their dynamical state and potentially skewing IMF estimates.
• The paper concludes that the rapid removal of gas from young clusters significantly impacts their structure and evolution, calling into question previous findings of non-standard IMFs in these clusters.
• The authors plan to expand their work by exploring the dynamical state of young clusters in more detail to constrain the star formation efficiency within them.
• The study acknowledges the support of various individuals and institutions, including the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope and the UK Astrophysical Fluids Facility.
• The research contributes to the understanding of star cluster evolution and the factors influencing the observed mass functions of clusters.
• The paper is based on observations with the Hubble Space

• Quantum fluctuations can suppress or enhance chaotic motion in wave packets, depending on the system and perturbation.
• The study numerically investigates the interplay between quantum fluctuation, tunneling, and decoherence in a one-dimensional double-well system driven by a polychromatic external field.
• The transition probability from one well to another is used to estimate the degree of coherence and classify motions as coherent or irregular.
• Coherent motion is characterized by a stable transition probability, while irregular motion shows fluctuations and a saturation of the uncertainty product due to quantum interference.
• The tunneling period decreases with increasing perturbation strength, which can be explained by the appearance of a stochastic layer near the separatrix, enhancing the instanton tunneling rate.
• Quantum fluctuations are larger for classically chaotic trajectories, suggesting that quantum corrections to phase space dynamics become more significant in chaotic systems.
• In the semiquantal approximation, partial quantum fluctuations enhance chaotic behavior, while full quantum interference suppresses it, indicating a breakdown of the semiquantal picture for delocalized states.
• The study also explores the classical phase space portraits and provides a simple explanation for the perturbed instanton tunneling picture, which relates to the reduction of the tunneling period in the coherent motion regime.
• The paper suggests that the polychromatic perturbation can be identified with a heat bath, and the chaotic behavior can induce one-way energy transport, a form of quantum dissipation.
• Theoretical expressions for the tunneling amplitude in chaos-assisted instanton tunneling are proposed, and the width of the stochastic layer is related to the tunneling amplitude.
• The study concludes that the polychromatic perturbation can lead to a transition from localized to delocalized behavior of the wave packet, with the chaotic dynamics playing a significant role in this process.
• The paper opens up avenues for further study on the reduction of tunneling periods and the critical strength of transition from localized to delocalized behavior in quantum systems.
• The research provides insights into the quantum-classical correspondence and the role of chaos in quantum t

* The study presents a unified stochastic framework to extend the understanding of dissipative quantum dynamics beyond standard bosonic bath models, incorporating non-interacting bosons, fermions, and spin baths. The framework introduces stochastic liouville equations with noise variables characterized by multi-time correlation functions, allowing for exact simulations of gaussian and non-gaussian baths.
* The paper develops generalized hierarchical equations (ghe) to deterministically simulate quantum dynamics for all three fundamental bath models, with spectral expansion for bosonic baths and generalized hierarchical equations for non-gaussian and fermionic baths. The dual-fermion mapping is also discussed for spin baths, transforming spins into fermionic degrees of freedom to efficiently handle non-gaussian properties.

* The glass transition in statistical physics, particularly the transition from a liquid to an amorphous solid, remains a complex problem with no clear resolution.
* Theoretical models suggest a thermodynamic transition at the Kauzmann temperature, but simulations of hard-disk systems have not confirmed this, leading to debates on model differences versus sampling issues.
* Mode coupling theory (MCT) offers an alternative view, suggesting a kinetic transition near a critical temperature, with both approaches supported by molecular simulations.
* The study uses molecular dynamics simulations to investigate the Ni@zr system, focusing on determining the glass transition temperature (T_0) from nonergodicity parameters and diffusion coefficients.
* The model employs the electron theoretical description of interatomic potentials, with no experimental parameters, and simulates heating and cooling to observe structural and dynamical properties.
* The simulations reveal that the shape of the partial structure factor is temperature-independent, and the incoherent intermediate scattering function shows a structural relaxation in three steps, consistent with the idealized MCT.
* Nonergodicity parameters, calculated using an iterative procedure, indicate a non-trivial solution at 1005 K, suggesting T_0 lies between 1000 and 1100 K.
* Memory functions derived from the simulations show a minimum at 0.1 ps, with a universal behavior below a certain time, and a crossover to quasi-arrested dynamics above a certain temperature.
* The @xmath0 estimates from diffusion coefficients and nonergodicity parameters differ, with diffusion-based estimates suggesting a lower T_0 around 950 K, while nonergodicity-based estimates predict a higher T_0 of 1005 K.
* The study concludes that the observed deviation between the estimates from the ergodic and nonergodic sides is smaller than the discrepancy found in soft-sphere models, suggesting a need for further investigation into the true value of T_0.
* The paper emphasizes the importance of considering both dynamical and static properties to understand the glass transition in transition metal alloys.
* The findings contribute to the ongoing effort to reconcile theoretical predictions with experimental observations of the glass transition in metallic glasses.
* The research highlights the potential of molecular dynamics

• The study addresses the challenges of analyzing longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts, focusing on the interdependence within dyads and the impact of one member's outcome on the other's.
• A Bayesian selection model-based approach is proposed, incorporating a transition model with dyad-specific random effects and a discrete time survival model for dropout.
• The approach accounts for within-dyad correlations and nonignorable dropouts, providing a more accurate analysis of dyadic data.
• Simulation studies demonstrate the proposed method's superior performance over complete-case and available-case analyses, with better bias and coverage rates.
• The method identifies significant "actor" and "partner" effects, revealing the interdependence of dyad members' outcomes and covariates.
• Applied to breast cancer data, the method suggests significant "partner" effects, indicating that patients and spouses influence each other's depression status.
• The study also finds nonignorable dropout for patients, suggesting that dropout is related to current depression scores, while spouse dropout appears ignorable.
• Sensitivity analysis shows the proposed method's robustness to different prior distributions and a more flexible dropout model.
• The proposed method provides insights for designing efficient prevention programs by considering the interdependence of patients and spouses.
• The study concludes that ignoring nonignorable dropouts can lead to missed covariate effects, emphasizing the importance of the proposed approach in dyadic data analysis.
• The research contributes to the understanding of dyadic relationships in psychosocial and behavioral studies, with implications for prevention program design.
• The study's findings highlight the need for further research on nonignorable dropout models and their application in various dyadic studies.
• The proposed Bayesian approach offers a comprehensive solution for analyzing longitudinal dyadic data, addressing both within-dyad correlations and nonignorable dropouts.
• The study's methodology and findings have potential applications in other dyadic studies beyond breast cancer research.
• The proposed approach is a significant advancement in the analysis of longitudinal dyadic data, with implications for social and behavioral research.

<summary>
* The paper discusses the torque induced by quantum fluctuations between two parallel birefringent plates, focusing on the Casimir-Lifshitz effect in anisotropic materials.
* The authors propose an experimental setup where a birefringent disk floats on a barium titanate plate in liquid ethanol, counterbalancing gravity with repulsive van der Waals forces.
* The torque magnitude is calculated to be on the order of nanonewton-meters at sub-micron distances, within the sensitivity of available instrumentation.
* The experiment's feasibility is questioned due to the technical challenge of keeping the disk at sub-micron separations without sticking, but a liquid ethanol medium is suggested to reduce surface interactions.
* Theoretical calculations show that the torque varies as the inverse of the square of the distance between the plates and has a maximum at specific angles and distances.
* The paper suggests that the experiment could be performed by using a laser beam to rotate the disk and then observing its return to equilibrium due to the torque from quantum fluctuations.
* The authors acknowledge that the dielectric function model used is relatively unprecise and that temperature effects are negligible at room temperature.
* They propose that the experiment could be optimized by using different materials or liquids with similar optical properties but lower viscosity.
* The paper also mentions that the torque's periodicity and its dependence on the initial position and material choice could help rule out spurious effects.
* The authors conclude that the experiment could demonstrate the rotation of the disk driven solely by quantum fluctuations, providing experimental validation of the Casimir-Lifshitz effect in anisotropic materials.
* The paper cites previous work on rotating small particles with light and suggests that the proposed experiment could achieve similar sensitivity.
* The authors thank colleagues for discussions and acknowledge partial support from the NSF under NNCI contract number PHY-0117795.
* The paper also references various works on the Casimir-Lifshitz effect, birefringence, and related theoretical and experimental studies.
* The authors suggest that further research could explore the effect in different configurations and materials, potentially impacting micro- and nano

• The paper introduces topologically biased random walks (tbrw) on graphs, using graph topological properties to bias random walks and explore network structure more efficiently, with applications in community detection and synchronization.
• The authors develop a perturbative approach to the spectrum of eigenvalues and eigenvectors, and propose a methodology for community detection using tbrw, demonstrating its potential through numerical simulations and theoretical analysis.

• The paper discusses the threat of active p2p worms that exploit popular p2p applications for rapid infection and the proposed holistic immunity system using phagocytes for defense.
• Phagocytes are specially elected p2p hosts with high immunity, managing groups of p2p hosts and monitoring their connection patterns and traffic volume to detect worm attacks.
• Upon detection, phagocytes isolate infected hosts, propagate worm alerts, and distribute software patches, effectively containing worm propagation within the p2p overlay.
• The system also provides external protection by hiding p2p host IP addresses and implementing an adaptive computational puzzle scheme at phagocytes to control access from external hosts.
• Experiments validate the system's effectiveness in various scenarios, showing that phagocytes can effectively defend against both internal and external p2p worm attacks without needing a large percentage of immune hosts or phagocytes.
• The paper concludes that the proposed system can protect p2p overlays from active p2p worms effectively, even in highly malicious environments, and suggests future work integrating with other systems and scalable DNS services.

• Two absorption components are detected toward hd32297, while only one is detected toward its proximate neighbors, suggesting the extra absorption is likely caused by circumstellar material.
• The interstellar medium (ISM) absorption is similar among hd32297 and its two closest neighbors, likely due to the boundary material of the local bubble.
• Some variation in local bubble absorption is detected toward 18 Ori, indicating small scale morphological variations in the local bubble shell.
• Radial velocities of hd32297, bd+07 777s, and bd+07 778 differ significantly, suggesting they are not physically associated.
• Temporal variability is detected in the spectrum of hd32297, indicating some red-shifted circumstellar absorption over several epochs.
• The circumstellar feature toward hd32297 is the strongest such absorption measured toward any nearby main sequence debris disk, 5 times greater than the column density of the prototypical edge-on debris disk, @xmath0 pic.
• Assuming similar morphology and abundances of the stable gas component around hd32297 to @xmath0 pic, an upper limit to the gas mass in the circumstellar disk is estimated at @xmath40.3 solar masses.
• Future observations are planned to monitor the temporal variability of the circumstellar gas toward hd32297 to determine the ratio of stable to variable gas and measure the gas disk absorption.
• The work was supported by NASA through a Hubble Fellowship grant, and the observations were made using the Hubble Space Telescope and the 2.7 m Harlan J. Smith Telescope at McDonald Observatory.
• The authors thank D. Doss, G. Harper, and A. Brown for their assistance with the observations, and an anonymous referee for insightful comments.
• The authors acknowledge the support of the Space Telescope Science Institute and the Association of Universities for Research in Astronomy, Inc. for NASA.

* The study explores quantum gravity corrections at the Planck time, utilizing various versions of the generalized uncertainty principle (GUP) instead of the standard Heisenberg uncertainty principle (HUP).
* The research finds that under specific conditions, quantum gravity effects can modify Planck-related quantities, potentially influencing early universe cosmology and observable phenomena like primordial gravitational waves.

* The paper explores new methods to compute couplings in conformal field theories (CFTs), focusing on scalar primary operators in @xmath0 su(N) and @xmath1 sym.
* The authors propose a method to compute couplings by deforming the CFT with a marginal or irrelevant operator @xmath0, introducing new divergences that are determined by the couplings @xmath1.
* In @xmath4 sym, the authors use integrability to diagonalize the anomalous dimension matrix at the CFT fixed point, which allows for the computation of couplings in perturbation theory.
* The paper also extends the computation of the string theory partition function for heavy strings using the ads/cft duality, including interactions with light fields and supergravity fields.
* The authors demonstrate that the computed couplings agree with the expected results from renormalization group arguments, providing confidence in the method's applicability to other chiral operators.
* The paper suggests that the proposed approach could lead to a systematic computation of couplings in CFTs using integrability, potentially uncovering new integrability structures.
* The authors acknowledge the contributions of colleagues and institutions that supported their research, including the FCT fellowship and CERN research grants.
* The paper concludes with open problems and the potential for further exploration of the duality in the context of more complex string configurations and higher point functions.
* The authors express gratitude for discussions with peers and sharing of preprints that contributed to the development of their work.
* The paper emphasizes the importance of the ads/cft duality in understanding the connection between gauge theories and string theory, particularly in the context of heavy string states and supergravity fields.
* The authors suggest that future work could extend the current approach to more general deformations and explore the implications for integrability in perturbative computations of couplings.
* The paper highlights the potential for new techniques to compute correlation functions of single trace operators in @xmath0 su(N) and @xmath1 sym, possibly leading to exact solutions using integrability.
* The authors suggest that the proposed method could be applied to other chiral operators, such as the energy-momentum tensor, by considering the action of the supersymmetry algebra on the anom

• The paper presents a relativistic embedding scheme for the Dirac equation, enabling the equation to be solved within a limited region of a larger system, with the influence of the rest of the system incorporated through an additional term in the Hamiltonian. This method is particularly useful for studying surface electronic structure problems and has been extended to relativistic cases, addressing issues such as spin-orbit splitting and relativistic effects in materials with heavier elements.

• The authors demonstrate the method's application by calculating the eigenstates of a confined hydrogen atom and the local density of states in a hydrogen cavity model, showing its stability and convergence to exact eigenvalues. They also illustrate the method's use in a silver monolayer sandwich structure, confirming its accuracy in reproducing the electronic structure of the embedded region.

* The paper studies adaptation mechanisms in the context of epidemics over arbitrary networks with heterogeneous node and edge dynamics.
* A lower bound on the epidemic threshold for the adaptive susceptible-infected-susceptible (heterogeneous asis) model is derived, which is proportional to the threshold in the standard sis model over static networks.
* An optimization framework is proposed to find cost-optimal adaptation rates for eradicating epidemics in the heterogeneous asis model.
* Theoretical results are confirmed with numerical simulations, and optimal adaptation rates are compared with popular centrality measures.
* The computational complexity of solving the optimization problem is shown to be polynomial in the size of the network.
* The paper introduces a geometric program to solve the optimization problem, which is a common approach for non-convex problems.
* The paper leaves the design of reconnecting rates as an open problem due to positivity constraints on decision variables.
* The paper concludes that betweenness centrality does not show a significant dependency on optimal cutting rates, unlike degree-based and eigenvector-based centralities.

* The study investigates the trace formula for flat 3D dielectric resonators, comparing experimental length spectra with semiclassical and exact trace formulas. The research focuses on the discrepancies between the experimental length spectra and the trace formula predictions, attributing them to the systematic error of the effective index of refraction approximation and the frequency dependence of the effective index. The study reveals that the semiclassical trace formula needs improvement for positions close to the critical angle and that the systematic error of the @xmath0 model, while small, can be identified and quantified. The results provide a refinement of techniques used in previous studies and contribute to the understanding of spectra of realistic microcavities and lasers.

* The paper presents a detailed comparison of experimental length spectra with semiclassical and exact trace formulas for flat 3D dielectric resonators, highlighting the need for higher-order corrections and a more accurate approximation for the effective index of refraction. The study concludes that the systematic error of the @xmath0 model and the frequency dependence of the effective index of refraction are significant factors affecting the accuracy of the trace formula. The research opens new perspectives for developing trace formulas for 3D dielectric cavities and refining techniques for understanding the spectra of realistic microcavities and lasers.

* The study estimates the gravitational wave background produced by double neutron star (NS-NS) mergers, using cosmic star formation rates and massive binary evolution models. It finds that a truly continuous background is formed only when sources are beyond a critical redshift, corresponding to a duty cycle condition. The maximum of the background density parameter occurs around 670 Hz for the sfr2 model and 630 Hz for the sfr1 model.

* The study also investigates the contribution of a "popcorn" noise from unresolved sources at high redshifts, which is one order of magnitude higher than the continuous background. This noise is expected to be detectable by future data analysis techniques.

* The study concludes that the gravitational wave background from NS-NS mergers is below the sensitivity of current detectors but could be within reach of future third-generation detectors. The popcorn noise, characterized by its spatial and temporal evolution, could also be distinguished from instrumental noise with adequate data analysis strategies.

• Diffusive acceleration at shock fronts is a nonlinear process, with backreaction of accelerated particles altering both particle spectrum and shock structure.
• Three approaches exist to account for particle backreaction: numerical simulations, fluid models, and analytical perturbative methods.
• Analytical approaches treat particle pressure as a small perturbation, suitable for weakly modified shocks, but recent solutions generalize to nonlinear regimes.
• Numerical simulations show that even small fractions of accelerated particles can significantly affect shock kinetic energy, challenging the test particle approximation.
• The paper presents a general analytical treatment for shock acceleration with both thermal and seed nonthermal particles, considering their nonlinear backreaction.
• The study extends previous work by including seed particles that can be re-energized by the shock, relevant for supernova shocks in the interstellar medium.
• The research identifies conditions for shock modification due to particle backreaction, revealing a critical behavior with multiple solutions for certain parameter ranges.
• The presence of seed particles can dominate shock modification, suggesting that nonlinear effects are significant in environments like our galaxy where cosmic rays and gas are in pressure equilibrium.
• The paper's findings have implications for the spectra of secondary nuclei from spallation processes, potentially altering our understanding of cosmic ray acceleration in astrophysical environments.
• The study's results are supported by simulations and suggest that nonlinear shock re-acceleration may be more influential than previously thought.
• The research acknowledges the need for further investigation, including comparison with numerical simulations, to fully understand the physical meaning of multiple solutions for modified shocks.
• The work was partially supported by grant Cofin 2002 at the Arcetri Astrophysical Observatory, with discussions contributing to the refinement of the study.

* The paper explores the implications of teleparallel gravity (TEGr) on Big Bang nucleosynthesis (BBN) and constrains TEGr models using BBN observational data.
* Three TEGr models, characterized by two free parameters each, are considered: the power-law, exponential, and square-root exponential models.
* Constraints from BBN are derived using the BBN equations and the BBN observational data on primordial abundance of light elements.
* The power-law model's exponent is constrained to be less than or equal to 1/2, in agreement with observational data.
* The exponential and square-root exponential models do not impose strict constraints on their parameters, as they always satisfy BBN bounds.
* The study concludes that viable TEGr models can satisfy BBN constraints, suggesting TEGr as a potential candidate for describing gravitational interactions.
* The paper emphasizes that TEGr could contribute to the debate on whether the universe's geometry is based on curvature or torsion.
* The work is supported by the COST Action CA15117, part of the European Cooperation in Science and Technology.
* BBN is a process that occurred in the early universe, forming light elements like hydrogen, helium, and lithium, and is used to test cosmological models.
* The BBN constraints are derived from the primordial abundances of these elements, which depend on the expansion rate of the universe and the temperature during BBN.
* The paper uses numerical values and equations to calculate the constraints on TEGr models, demonstrating that BBN can provide stringent tests for these models.
* The authors suggest that TEGr models, which satisfy basic observational tests and BBN constraints, could be a successful alternative to general relativity and other gravity theories.
* The paper concludes that TEGr models, which are consistent with observational BBN data, could potentially describe the gravitational interaction in the universe.
* The authors highlight the importance of considering TEGr in the context of cosmological models and its implications for understanding the universe's expansion and structure.
* The paper is part of a broader effort to explore alternative theories of gravity and their implications for cosmology and astrophysics.
* The authors acknowledge the support of the COST Action CA15117, which aims

* The paper presents an optimal mode selection and power allocation policy for a three-node half-duplex bidirectional relay network with fading links, aiming to maximize the sum rate.
* Six transmission modes are possible in the network, and the policy selects the optimal mode and power allocation for each time slot based on instantaneous channel state information (CSI).
* The policy considers a joint average power constraint for all nodes and uses a threshold-based approach to determine the optimal transmit powers and mode selection.
* The optimal policy does not select certain modes (e.g., direct transmission modes) and instead focuses on modes that involve relay transmission, achieving higher sum rates.
* The paper proves that the optimal solution requires binary decisions for mode selection and power allocation, and relaxing this constraint does not affect the maximum average sum rate.
* Simulation results confirm that the proposed protocol outperforms existing protocols, such as the traditional two-way relaying protocol and the time division broadcast (TDB) protocol, especially at low total average transmit power.
* The proposed protocol's performance is benchmarked against the time division broadcast protocol with and without power allocation, as well as buffer-aided relay protocols.
* The paper also discusses the potential for future research on delay analysis of the proposed protocol, noting that it is beyond the scope of the current work.
* The authors note that while buffering increases end-to-end delay, modifications to the optimal protocol can bound the average delay, causing only a small loss in the achieved rate.
* The paper concludes by emphasizing the importance of instantaneous CSI and long-term channel statistics in achieving the maximum sum rate in the considered bidirectional relay network.

• The cosmic microwave background (CMB) anisotropy power spectrum allows for the measurement of a "standard ruler" scale at low redshifts, which can constrain the universe's matter and energy content.
• If CMB measurements are misled by undetected relativistic particles, it could bias inferences, but the ratio of baryon to photon density, robustly measured in the CMB, ensures unchanged dark energy inferences.
• The sound horizon, crucial for interpreting acoustic oscillations, depends only on the baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality, not on the physical matter density.
• The CMB accurately measures the baryon-to-photon ratio and the epoch of matter-radiation equality, which are essential for determining the sound horizon and thus the standard ruler scale.
• The Hubble constant does not affect the sound horizon, and only the ratio of radiation to matter densities matters for the acoustic oscillation standard ruler method.
• The presence of undetectable new radiation does not impact the acoustic peak method as long as the redshift of equality is correctly measured.
• The acoustic oscillation scale can be measured at high redshifts using galaxy surveys, providing a way to test for dynamical anomalies in the early universe.
• The CMB's sensitivity to radiation density and its quadrupole moment allows for the detection of non-photon radiation, potentially revealing new relativistic species.
• Precision measurements of the matter power spectrum can constrain the presence of unknown relativistic components, and the Hubble constant can be independently determined from observations.

• The paper discusses the excitement around determining neutrino masses and mixing angles from oscillation experiments, with a focus on the potential of neutrinos to reveal new physics beyond the Standard Model.
• The authors propose an ansatz for the 3-generation neutrino mass matrix derived from an SO(10) grand unified model, motivated by the unification of quark and lepton masses.
• They explore the consequences of their ansatz by combining it with experimental data on neutrino oscillations, aiming to reconstruct the neutrino mass matrix and infer the neutrino mass spectrum.
• The paper examines the implications of neutrino masses for processes like neutrinoless double beta decay, which could provide constraints on the neutrino mass matrix.
• The authors find two essentially different solutions for the neutrino mass matrix when assuming the neutrinos are Majorana particles and the neutrino mass matrix is real, with one solution featuring two neutrinos of nearly equal mass and a third with a distinct mass.
• They also consider solutions for a complex neutrino mass matrix, which introduce CP-violating phases affecting only the neutrinoless double beta decay process, not ordinary neutrino oscillations.
• The paper concludes that neutrinos could play a role in cosmology if their masses are large enough, and the type ii solutions with complex neutrino mass matrices are on the borderline of being ruled out by non-observation of neutrinoless double beta decay.

* The Levi-Civita (LC) spacetime, characterized by two essential constants, presents challenges in interpretation, especially when considering the parameter @xmath0, which relates to the topology of spacetime and gravitational effects akin to the Aharonov-Bohm effect. The LC spacetime is described by a metric that becomes flat for certain values of @xmath0, and it is known to lack horizons, suggesting an upper limit to the mass per unit length of line sources.

* The paper proposes gedanken experiments with a gyroscope to explore the interpretation of LC spacetime, particularly focusing on the behavior of gyroscopic precession as a function of different variables. The results indicate that the interpretation of the coordinate @xmath2 as an azimuthal angle in LC spacetime with @xmath0=16 is questionable, as the precession behavior differs from that in flat space or the FLRW metric. The paper concludes that the simultaneous interpretation of LC spacetime with @xmath0=16 and @xmath0=14 as due to infinite planes of positive or negative mass density is problematic, and the meaning of @xmath2 in LC spacetime with @xmath0=16 as an azimuthal angle seems to be different from its usual interpretation.

• Quantum channel estimation is crucial for quantum communication, but challenging due to limited resources.
• The paper introduces cost functions to quantify estimation quality, focusing on statistical error and fidelity mean error.
• Protocols for estimating parameters of one-parameter quantum channels like depolarizing, phase damping, and amplitude damping are proposed.
• For pauli channels, entanglement-based estimation methods outperform single-qubit schemes, enhancing parameter estimation.
• The paper extends the estimation strategy to higher-dimensional quantum channels, demonstrating the versatility of entanglement.
• The study emphasizes the importance of entanglement in quantum information processing and the potential for improved quantum communication protocols.
• The research was supported by various programs, including the dfg programme "quantum information processing," the european science foundation qit programme, and the european commission's "qubits" and "quest" programs.
• The authors acknowledge discussions and remarks from V. Buek and contributions from other researchers in the field.

• The study establishes a comprehensive mathematical model for high-energy nuclear collision phenomenology, focusing on the @xmath5 dependence of single-particle spectra and two-dimensional angular correlations. It confronts issues related to the connection between @xmath5 and collision centrality, the relevance of centrality, and the nature of the underlying event (UE).

• The research introduces a three-component model for hadron production, including soft (projectile proton dissociation), hard (parton fragmentation to minimum-bias dijets), and nonjet (quadrupole) components, and explores their correspondence with centrality, UE structure, dijet production, and the partonic structure of projectile protons.

• The study presents new measurements of single-particle density and two-dimensional angular correlations, extending the two-component model to include a nonjet quadrupole component. It also presents a three-component model for @xmath2 densities and the @xmath2-acceptance dependence of transverse-rapidity spectra.

• The findings suggest that centrality, as determined by impact parameter, may not be a useful concept for high-energy nuclear collisions. Instead, variations in soft and hard components of hadron production may depend on the event-wise depth of penetration on momentum fraction @xmath3 of the projectile wave functions. The study also challenges the existence of a UE and the interpretation of a nonjet quadrupole component as evidence of collectivity or hydrodynamic flow in small collision systems.

<summary>
* The principle of quantum superposition is crucial in quantum mechanics, with its preservation and destruction being central to quantum-to-classical transitions and technological applications.
* Environmental interactions cause decoherence in quantum systems, traditionally modeled by markovian master equations, but recent work generalizes this to nonmarkovian cases using stochastic methods.
* The study introduces random evolution operators to model environmental effects, showing that both markovian and nonmarkovian master equations can be derived from averaged random unitary evolutions.
* The approach allows for fast solutions to master equations when unitary solutions are known, exemplified by solving the phase-damping Jaynes-Cummings model in the rotating-wave approximation.
* The formalism naturally generalizes intrinsic decoherence models, offering a unified framework for understanding decoherence in both markovian and nonmarkovian regimes.
* The paper also discusses the physical implications of intrinsic decoherence and compares the proposed formalism with experimental results in cavity QED and ion traps, suggesting that decoherence can arise from approximations in the system's description.
* The work concludes by highlighting the versatility of stochastic methods in quantum mechanics and the potential for future research in quantum information processing and scalability.
</summary>

* The study numerically calculates the localization length of light in one-dimensional disordered systems with alternating layers of different indices of refraction and thicknesses.
* For homogeneous stacks, the localization length exhibits a quadratic dependence on wavelength at long wavelengths, saturating at low values, and is modulated by allowed bands, decreasing with increasing disorder.
* In mixed stacks with alternating left- and right-handed materials, the localization length at long wavelengths linearly depends on wavelength, with a slope inversely proportional to the modulus of the reflection amplitude between layers.
* The study also finds that the localization length in non-symmetric band distributions, where the optical path condition is not satisfied, presents an irregular form across the transmission spectrum, with more pronounced changes in mixed stacks.

• The cosmological model aligns with observational data, indicating that ordinary matter (baryonic) makes up only 4% of the universe's mass-energy, with 23% being non-baryonic dark matter and 73% being mysterious dark energy, as shown in the "cosmic cheesecake" model.
• Dark matter, possibly in the form of weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPs), is crucial for the formation of large structures, while dark energy, represented by a cosmological constant, drives the universe's expansion.
• Modified Newtonian Dynamics (MOND) is proposed as an alternative to dark matter, suggesting a modification of gravity at low accelerations, but it faces challenges in explaining galaxy rotation curves and large-scale structure observations.
• Theories of modified gravity, such as tense-vector-scalar (TEVES) and gravitational modification (GravMod), attempt to explain MOND without invoking dark matter, but they struggle with issues like the formation of galaxy satellites and the Tully-Fisher relation.
• A new approach, gravitational polarization, suggests dark matter could be a polarizable medium, analogous to the polarization in dielectrics, which could explain MOND without violating fundamental principles.
• This polarizable dark matter model, while not microscopically grounded, offers a unification of dark matter and dark energy and is consistent with the observed value of the cosmological constant, but it remains to be tested against cosmological observations.

* The study investigates the phase behavior of polyampholytes (PAs), flexible polymers with fixed charges, using a complete enumeration approach for configurations up to 13 monomers on a cubic lattice.
* The research reveals that PAs with excess charge @xmath11 cannot form a compact state in any space dimension @xmath7, with a critical charge @xmath12.
* The probability of a PA having an excess charge depends on both @xmath7 and its length, with a transition from a globular to a stretched configuration occurring at @xmath13 for @xmath14.
* The study provides detailed energetics and spatial conformations of short PAs, supporting previous Monte Carlo (MC) simulations and suggesting a phase transition at low temperatures for small excess charges.
* The results indicate that PAs with small excess charges may undergo a phase transition between two dense states, a phenomenon not detected in MC studies due to low temperature constraints.

• Half-metallic ferromagnets with high Curie temperatures are ideal for spintronics, with cr-doped dilute magnetic semiconductors (DMS) and their alloys being of particular interest.
• Theoretical calculations and experimental growth of zinc blende (zb) structure thin films of DMS have shown their half-metallic character and high Curie temperatures.
• Theoretical studies suggest that the half-metallic ferromagnetic character of ordered zb compounds of transition metals and pnictogens/chalcogenides is preserved over a wide range of lattice parameters.
• The ground states of many DMS compounds differ from the zb structure, with the most common being the hexagonal NiAs-type structure.
• Some compounds like CrSb, CrSe, and CrTe are epitaxially unstable against the NiAs structure, while CrSb and CrSe are stable at larger lattice constants.
• Theoretical calculations reveal that CrS is antiferromagnetic at equilibrium lattice parameter, thus not half-metallic, which presents a challenge for experimental synthesis.
• Recent advances in molecular beam epitaxy have enabled the growth of thicker zb-CrSb films, indicating progress in material synthesis techniques.
• The study aims to investigate the variation of magnetic properties, particularly exchange interactions and Curie temperature, of Cr-based pnictides and chalcogenides as a function of lattice parameter.
• Theoretical calculations for CrAs, CrSb, CrSe, and CrTe were performed using the tb-lmto-cpa method and the Vosko-Wilk-Nusair exchange-correlation potential.
• The study found that CrAs and CrSb are robust ferromagnets over a wide range of lattice parameters, while CrSe and CrTe may have antiferromagnetic or complex magnetic ground states at low lattice parameters.
• The study also revealed that the Curie temperature of these compounds varies with lattice parameter, with the highest temperatures observed for CrAs and CrSb.
• The study suggests that pnictide-chalcogenide alloys could be promising for stabilizing the zb structure on various substrates and achieving half-metallic ferromagnetic states.
• The study provides

• The study calculates the temperature structure and spectroscopic signatures of x-ray illuminated disks, considering thermal conduction and phase equilibrium in the gas. It reveals that the presence of an intermediate stable layer can enhance soft x-ray emission and reflection lines, which may be observable with high-resolution spectroscopy.

• The existence of an intermediate stable layer is justified for certain continuum spectra, and its impact on the detectability of recombination and reflection lines is discussed, with potential observability in obscured seyfert 2 galaxies.

• The study's findings suggest that the unique ionization parameters of transition layers and the intermediate stable layer depend on the incident continuum's shape, with implications for the observability of x-ray line features in active galactic nuclei and black hole binaries.

<summary>
* The study examines the transverse distribution function of a three-dimensional wormlike chain with a fixed orientation and end, using quantum mechanics and quantum field theory.
* The paper explores the bimodal shape of the transverse distribution function for intermediate chain lengths, which is a manifestation of semiflexibility.
* Analytical results for short and long wormlike chains are presented, agreeing with previous findings obtained through different methods.
* The transverse distribution function is expressed in terms of matrix elements of the green function of the quantum rigid rotator in a homogeneous external field.
* The paper provides a compact form for the Fourier-Laplace transform of the distribution function, involving infinite order matrices that are truncated for calculations.
* The short chain limit is expanded in inverse powers of the chain end-to-end distance, leading to a series expansion that matches the plane wave expansion for a stiff rod.
* The paper computes the anisotropic moments for small chain lengths, finding a first-order correction consistent with the WKB method and a new second-order correction.
* The end-to-end distribution function for large chain lengths is expanded in inverse powers of the chain end-to-end distance, revealing a bimodal shape with a peak at a finite transverse displacement.
* The bimodal behavior of the projected distribution function is attributed to inhomogeneities in curvature fluctuations near the clamped end of the chain.
* The paper confirms the bimodal shape of the transverse distribution function for intermediate chain lengths through numerical calculations and comparison with Monte Carlo simulations.
* The study demonstrates excellent agreement between the computed three-dimensional distribution function and Monte Carlo simulation data.
* The paper concludes that the transverse distribution function of the free end of the 3D wormlike chain exhibits a bimodal shape for intermediate chain lengths, with a peak at a finite transverse displacement.
* The paper also presents analytical considerations for short and long polymers, in complete agreement with classical works.
* The authors discuss the accuracy of the calculations, which depends on the truncation of infinite order matrices and the number of terms in the expansion over the Legendre polynomials.
* The paper's findings contribute to the understanding of semiflexible polymers and their potential applications in bi

* The paper aims to characterize when a connected graph has a closed labeling, focusing on properties directly observable from the graph.
* Closed graphs are defined as graphs with a closed labeling, where edges point towards the larger label, and binomial edge ideals are linked to these labelings.
* The main theorem states that a connected graph is closed if and only if it is chordal, claw-free, and narrow.
* Closed graphs are also chordal and claw-free, and the paper explores the implications of these properties.
* The paper introduces an algorithm for labeling connected graphs, which assigns labels to vertices in a specific order based on their connectivity.
* The algorithm's output is shown to satisfy the necessary conditions for a closed labeling, proving the converse of the main theorem.
* The paper also discusses the properties of layers in a graph, which are related to the algorithm's labeling process.
* The paper concludes by proving that the algorithm's labeling produces a closed labeling for any connected, chordal, claw-free, and narrow graph.
* The authors acknowledge the support of Amherst College and Michael Ching for their contributions to the research.
* The paper builds upon previous work on binomial edge ideals and their connection to graph properties.
* The paper's results have implications for the study of binomial edge ideals and their Gröbner bases.
* The paper's findings contribute to the understanding of graph labeling and its applications in algebraic structures.
* The paper's results have potential applications in combinatorics, graph theory, and algebraic geometry.

* The cosmic ray spectrum, known for its featureless power law energy spectrum, presents a challenge at energies above a few hundred tev due to the need for techniques that utilize extensive air showers developed in the atmosphere.
* Recent observations suggest a change in the spectral slope just above 100 ev, and while there's no clear evidence of anisotropy, the composition of cosmic rays at these energies is crucial for understanding their origin.
* The study of inclined showers, which are air showers with zenith angles above 60 degrees, offers a new method to analyze cosmic ray composition, doubling the acceptance of air shower arrays and providing insights into the primary particle nature.
* The Haverah Park array's analysis of inclined showers suggests a significant photon component at ultra-high energies, with a photon fraction below a certain confidence level, indicating that cosmic rays at these energies may not be protons but likely photons or light nuclei.

• Cold atoms in optical lattices combine atomic physics and quantum optics, creating artificial crystals of light for trapping atoms.
• Atoms in these lattices can form quantum matter crystals, akin to eggs in an egg carton, allowing for controlled arrangements.
• The study of quantum behavior in these systems has led to the observation of the superfluid to mott insulator transition, a key phenomenon in condensed matter physics.
• The history of Bose-Einstein condensation (BEC) began with Bose's rules for photons and Einstein's extension to other bosons, predicting condensation at low temperatures.
• The observation of BEC in rubidium atoms in 1995 led to the realization of the superfluid to mott insulator transition in cold atoms, opening new avenues for condensed matter physics simulations.
• Ultracold atoms in optical lattices can simulate various condensed matter phenomena, including spin ordering, using the Hubbard model and its extensions.
• The double-well optical lattice setup allows for the study of spin Hamiltonians by dynamically controlling lattice parameters.
• The Hubbard model, extended to include spin degrees of freedom, can be used to investigate spin ordering in cold atoms.
• The ground state of the system depends on the tunneling rate, interaction strength, and potential bias, with the ground state transitioning from singlet to triplet states as parameters vary.
• Theoretical calculations using the correlated variational approach can predict ground state energies and wavefunctions, revealing the effects of interactions on spin ordering.
• The inclusion of inter-site interactions, such as Coulomb and exchange interactions, can induce spin ordering in the system, mimicking magnetic phenomena in metals.
• The ground state energy and wavefunction can be controlled by adjusting the model parameters, allowing for the study of dynamic properties and transitions between different magnetic states.
• The extended Hubbard model can be tested against experimental data, providing insights into the physics of transition metals and the potential for educational applications.
• The study of cold atoms in optical lattices has reached a stage where it can impact curricula, offering a novel approach to teaching condensed matter physics concepts.
• The pedagogical study aims to introduce the investigation of spin ordering

• The study addresses the complexities of understanding the magnetic anisotropy in iron pnictides and its influence on angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES) data, focusing on detwinned crystals to avoid averaging effects from twinning.
• The research uses the Korringa-Kohn-Rostoker-Green's function approach with coherent potential approximation to accurately model disorder and reproduces the electronic structure and ARPES spectra of iron pnictides, revealing the anisotropic features and their evolution with co substitution, and suggesting an as-terminated surface as the most probable surface termination for the studied compound.

* The m31 globular cluster b158 (xb158) is a bright X-ray source discovered by the Einstein Observatory, showing strong intensity modulation on a 10,017-second period during the 2002 January XMM-Newton observation.
* Analysis of XMM-Newton observations from 1991 and 2000 revealed decreasing modulation amplitude with increasing source intensity, suggesting a neutron star binary with a low mass donor and a separation of about 510 cm.
* However, a single deep dip in the 2000 June XMM-Newton observation, absent in previous cycles, led to the hypothesis of a precessing disk, associated with the "superhump" phenomenon in low mass ratio systems.
* Swift observations from 2013 February 8 to March 9 revealed a 5.65-day super-orbital period for xb158, with a luminosity variation factor of 15, consistent with the range observed in Chandra's 13+ year monitoring campaign.
* The super-orbital period is longer than the predicted 81 hours from 3D smoothed particle hydrodynamical modeling, possibly due to a lower mass ratio between the donor and the accretor.
* The XMM-Newton spectrum of xb158 was best described by a blackbody plus power law model, with a photon index of 0.57, indicating a neutron star accretor rather than a black hole.
* The authors thank the Swift team and anonymous referees for their contributions to this work, which was funded by Swift grant NNX13AJ76 G.

* The paper presents a method to calculate resonance energies and lifetimes by analyzing the convergence properties of variational eigenvalues obtained from different basis set sizes.
* The method involves selecting a set of eigenvalues that exhibit linear convergence with basis set size, using properties of the variational spectrum.
* The paper demonstrates the method's effectiveness through models of one and two particles, showing that the selected eigenvalues converge to the correct resonance values when extrapolated.
* The paper also discusses the calculation of resonance widths using a golden rule-like formula, which, despite not being exact, provides a good approximation when extrapolated.
* The authors note that the method's applicability may be limited for systems with more than three particles due to difficulties in handling large basis sets.
* The paper concludes that the proposed method improves the calculation of resonance energies and lifetimes, with the potential for further refinement in lifetime calculations.
* The authors acknowledge that the appearance of bundles in the spectrum, while not fully understood, is supported by numerical evidence and suggests a general behavior.
* The paper includes an appendix with arguments supporting the scaling of eigenenergies with the basis set parameter, applicable to one-body hamiltonians and potentially to more particles with fast-decaying pair interactions at large distances.
* The paper's findings contribute to a better understanding of the convergence properties of variational methods in resonance state calculations.

* The study extends the concept of @xmath0-symmetric systems to two-dimensional plaquettes, aiming to construct fundamental building blocks for @xmath0-symmetric two-dimensional lattices. The researchers introduce four basic types of plaquettes, including configurations with four and five sites. The configurations are inspired by earlier works on two-dimensional Hamiltonian lattices and discrete solitary vortices.

* The plaquettes are described by a multicomponent nonlinear Schrödinger equation (NLSE) built over a transposition-symmetric linear Hermitian matrix Hamiltonian and an additional nonlinear matrix operator. The symmetry properties of the NLSE are analyzed, revealing that the nonlinear terms are not matrix-wise symmetric but exhibit a different form of symmetry.

* Stationary solutions are sought over the gain-loss parameter, with their stability analyzed numerically. The study identifies various solution branches, some of which terminate at critical points of the linear systems, while others continue due to nonlinearity. The spectral stability of configurations is examined, revealing that most stationary modes are unstable, but stable branches exist.

* The dynamics of the modes belonging to different branches are studied through direct simulations. Unstable modes typically lead to the growth of amplitudes at gain-carrying sites and decay at lossy ones. Passive sites may be driven towards growth or decay, depending on the particular solution. The study suggests further exploration of more sophisticated stationary modes resulting from symmetry breaking and the potential existence of isolated solutions versus branches of solutions in @xmath0-symmetric systems.

* The work lays the groundwork for future studies on two-dimensional @xmath0-symmetric lattice systems and even three-dimensional ones. The researchers propose constructing periodic two-dimensional lattices of the presented building blocks and identifying counterparts of the modes in infinite lattices, along with new modes that may exist in such cases. The study also hints at the possibility of constructing three-dimensional @xmath0-symmetric lattices, starting with a @xmath0-symmetric cube composed of eight sites.

• The cataclysmic variable HU Aqr consists of a white dwarf accreting from a companion star, with the system orbited by two planets. The inner planet's orbit allows for the determination of the rate of mass loss during the common envelope phase, while the outer planet's orbit helps validate this calculation and determine the conditions of the system's birth. The presence of these planets offers unique diagnostics to constrain the origin and evolution of the system, despite the planets' catastrophic evolutionary history.

• The binary system's initial conditions, including the masses of the primary and secondary stars and their orbital separation, are constrained by the requirement for stable mass transfer post common envelope phase. The initial binary separation and planetary orbital separations are determined within a factor of 5, and the initial rate of mass loss from the common envelope is measured within a factor of 2.

• The reconstructed evolution of the binary system enables the calculation of two parameters: the initial binary separation and the rate of mass loss during the common envelope phase. The derived rate of mass loss for HU Aqr is consistent with common - envelope studies, and the initial binary separation is bracketed by the derived range.

• The inner planet's formation time and the outer planet's final orbit are used to further constrain the initial conditions of the binary system. The dynamical stability of the system is tested by integrating the entire system's orbit for 1myr, and the stable systems are identified based on the semi-major axis and eccentricity of the planets.

• The study demonstrates the potential of using circumbinary planets to reconstruct the evolution of cataclysmic variable systems. The findings provide insights into the common - envelope phase and the conditions under which cataclysmic variables are born, with implications for understanding the formation and survival of planetary systems around such dynamically complex environments.

• The experimental evidence of skyrmions in non-centrosymmetric compounds with Dzyoloshinskii-Moriya ( DMI) interaction has intrigued scientists, with MnSi thin films on Si substrates offering promising prospects for spintronic devices due to their interesting magnetic phases and ease of device integration.
• The main drawback of MnSi films is their low magnetic ordering temperature, prompting the search for compounds with similar spin order at higher temperatures, such as MnGe, which has a higher magnetic ordering temperature of 170K.
• MnGe films have been successfully grown on Si(111) substrates using a MnSi seedlayer, with the aim of achieving a b20 crystal structure and enhanced magnetic ordering temperatures.
• The MnGe thin films exhibit a b20 structure confirmed by reflection high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED) and X-ray diffraction (XRD), with a lattice parameter slightly smaller than bulk MnGe due to compressive strain from the Si substrate.
• Atomic force microscopy (AFM) reveals island growth of Volmer-Weber type, with island size increasing with film thickness, and morphology transforming into elongated islands.
• Magnetization measurements show that the MnGe films have a magnetic structure related to antiferromagnetism, with a shorter helix length than MnSi, resulting in a more rigid helical structure.
• The magnetic susceptibility of MnGe films indicates an enhanced ordering temperature of 200K, with no critical fields observed up to 5T, suggesting a more rigid helical structure than MnSi.
• Resistivity measurements show that the MnGe thin films are metallic with a residual resistivity at 3K of 83 cm, and the magnetoresistivity effect is negative with no remarkable features in the investigated field range.
• The absence of magnetic phase transitions in moderate magnetic fields and small magnetoresistivity in MnGe thin films suggests a stronger DMI interaction compared to MnSi.
• The successful growth of MnGe thin films on Si(111) substrates opens new opportunities for high-temperature spintronic devices, with potential applications in data storage.

• The paper aims to prove that the core entropy function, which measures the complexity of the dynamics of quadratic polynomials on their hubbard trees, extends continuously from the external angles of the Mandelbrot set to the complex plane. This result answers a question posed by W. Thurston and generalizes the entropy theory of real quadratic maps to complex polynomials.

• The authors develop an algorithm that computes the core entropy by considering pairs of postcritical angles, avoiding the need to know the topology of the hubbard tree. They construct a directed graph whose growth rate, defined as the smallest zero of a certain function, coincides with the core entropy for rational angles. The paper also introduces combinatorial tools to study the growth rates of countable graphs and applies these to the core entropy, proving its continuity and H\"older continuity at rational angles.

• The detection of afterglows from gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) supports the fireball model, but the exact nature of GRBs, whether they are highly collimated jets or isotropic fireballs, remains uncertain. Three methods have been proposed to determine the degree of beaming in GRBs, but each has its limitations.

• The first method involves analyzing light curve breaks in optical afterglows, but various factors can mimic these breaks, making it inconclusive. The second method suggests that optical afterglows from jetted GRBs could be polarized, but this requires specific conditions to observe. The third method relies on the detection of "orphan afterglows," which are not associated with any detected GRBs, to measure the GRB collimation angle.

• However, the identification of orphan afterglows is challenging due to the unknown trigger time and the potential presence of "failed gamma-ray bursts" (fGRBs) that are baryon-contaminated fireballs with lower Lorentz factors. These fGRBs could also produce orphan afterglows, complicating the interpretation of observations.

• Theoretical models predict that fGRBs should have a similar light curve to successful isotropic GRBs in the early stages, but with a different late-time behavior. However, the uncertainty in the trigger time makes it difficult to derive a satisfactory light curve for orphan afterglows.

• Possible solutions to discriminate between fGRB orphans and jetted GRB orphans include improving detection limits, identifying fast x-ray transients associated with fGRBs, using radio observations, and considering future detections of gravitational waves or neutrino emissions. The redshift of the orphan afterglow can also provide valuable information.

• The concept of fGRBs is based on the assumption that most GRB progenitor models involve baryon-rich environments, leading to many failed GRBs. However, if GRBs are due to phase transitions of neutron stars to strange stars or collisions of binary strange stars, the number of fGRBs would be significantly lower.

• The XMM-Newton satellite observed two gamma-ray burst (GRB) afterglows, GRB 011211 and GRB 001025, providing valuable data on their X-ray spectra.

• GRB 011211's afterglow was identified with an optical transient, and a decline in X-ray flux during observation supported this identification.

• GRB 001025's X-ray afterglow was detected later and had a lower flux, but its spectrum was similar to GRB 011211's, suggesting it was also an afterglow.

• No significant absorption above galactic values was detected in either GRB's X-ray spectra, challenging the idea that bursts in star-forming regions cause high absorption.

• A proposed complex of blue-shifted lines in GRB 011211's spectrum was not statistically significant, and the spectrum appeared featureless, supporting the afterglow identification.

* The layered organic material ai3, under hydrostatic pressure, exhibits both high-mobility massless Dirac fermions and low-mobility massive carriers, unlike graphene.
* Ai3's average Fermi velocity is about one order of magnitude smaller than graphene's, suggesting the importance of electronic correlations.
* The effective Coulomb interaction constant is expected to be ten times larger in ai3 than in graphene due to the inverse proportionality to Fermi velocity.
* Ai3's band structure calculations predict additional massive carriers near the Fermi level, which has not been experimentally confirmed until now.
* Magneto-transport measurements under hydrostatic pressure reveal the coexistence of high-mobility Dirac carriers and low-mobility massive holes in ai3.
* The temperature dependence of carrier densities and mobilities supports a two-carrier scenario, with dirac carriers and massive carriers both present.
* Thermopower measurements corroborate the two-carrier scenario, showing a sign change in the Seebeck coefficient around 5K.
* The mobility ratio of massless Dirac carriers to massive carriers is consistent with the presence of both carrier types under high pressure.
* The study suggests that dirac carriers dominate conduction at low magnetic fields and high temperatures, while massive carriers dominate at high magnetic fields and low temperatures.
* The coexistence of dirac and massive carriers in ai3 holds with little perturbation across the pressure range studied.
* Complementary studies, such as spectroscopic measurements, are recommended for a more comprehensive understanding of ai3's carrier dynamics.
* The research provides insights into strongly correlated Dirac fermions beyond the scope of graphene, with potential implications for future electronic and spintronic devices.
* The findings contribute to the broader understanding of topological materials and their unique electronic properties.
* The study's experimental approach and results offer a foundation for further exploration of ai3 and similar materials.
* The research highlights the potential of ai3 for applications in low-power electronics and quantum computing.
* The study's findings may inspire further investigation into the interplay between Dirac fermions and massive carriers in other materials.

• The spin resonance peak in inelastic neutron scattering ( ins) in iron pnictides and chalcogenides ( febs) can be identified as the true spin resonance if it occurs below the indirect gap scale, which is determined by the sum of gaps on different fermi surface sheets connected by the scattering wave vector @xmath2. This criterion helps to confirm the @xmath7 gap symmetry in the superconducting state.

• The peak frequency in ins and the maximal and minimal gap sizes extracted from various experimental techniques suggest that the observed feature in ins is the spin resonance, evidencing the sign-changing gap structure. However, definitive conclusions require calculations of the dynamical spin susceptibility for the specific experimental band structure.

• There are cases where the peak frequency in ins does not match the indirect gap scale, leading to ambiguity about the nature of the peak. For instance, if one of the gaps is @xmath0, there are three possible scenarios: the peak is the spin resonance, it is not the spin resonance, or it is the spin resonance but the definitive conclusion requires further calculations.

• The study introduces a 2D generalization of the dual random dimer model (2d-DRDM), which, like its 1D counterpart, can create delocalized states in the spectrum around a resonance energy, independent of system dimensionality.
• In the context of a weakly interacting Bose gas on a 2D lattice, the 2d-DRDM drives spatial homogeneity of the ground state, leading to non-monotonic behavior and enhancement of the condensate fraction near the resonance energy.
• The study employs a mode-matching argument that includes interaction effects, revealing that the resonance energy, which minimizes spatial fluctuations, is crucial for understanding the impact of correlated disorder on coherence and ground state properties in the weakly interacting regime.

• The paper investigates the maximum independent set problem for generalized Petersen graphs, focusing on bounds and exact values for the independence number (@xmath2).
• The authors provide an upper bound for the independence number when the graph is even and present lower bounds when the graph has an even number of vertices.
• They prove behsaz-hatami-mahmoodian's conjecture for certain cases and establish that the independence number can be found in linear time for any fixed @xmath8.
• The paper also shows that the treewidth of generalized Petersen graphs is bounded for any fixed @xmath8, allowing for efficient dynamic programming solutions.

• Quantum key distribution (QKD) is secure against eavesdropping if users' devices meet certain requirements, but practical systems often fail to meet these, leading to security vulnerabilities.
• Device-independent security proofs are theoretically interesting but don't apply to practical systems with testing loopholes.
• Measurement Device Independent QKD (MDiQKD) eliminates detector loopholes, but the measurement unit can be controlled by an eavesdropper, raising concerns about its practicality.
• MDiQKD schemes have been proposed, with one using phase locking and another converting phase encoding to polarization encoding, both requiring perfect signal source preparation.
• The security of these schemes is proven against general quantum attacks, assuming the signal source preparation is nearly perfect.
• Imperfections in phase modulators introduce basis-dependent flaws, reducing the achievable key generation distance.
• Simulations show that the phase encoding scheme with phase locking can generate keys over shorter distances but allows control over the basis-dependent flaw by adjusting pulse intensities.
• The phase encoding scheme with polarization conversion requires precise single-photon state preparation and is less tolerant to imperfections, but can cover longer distances with current technology.
• The feasibility of both schemes depends on the accuracy of phase modulation and the fidelity of single-photon states, highlighting the importance of precise state preparation in QKD.
• The paper suggests that future studies should focus on the experimental realization of these schemes, considering the practical limitations of current technologies.
• The authors acknowledge support from various institutions and express gratitude for hospitality during a visit to the University of Toronto.
• The paper concludes by emphasizing the significance of accurate state preparation in both MDiQKD and standard QKD to avoid basis-dependent flaws.

• Modified theories of gravity, particularly @xmath0 gravity, have gained attention for explaining the accelerated expansion of the universe, with dark energy being a central focus. Researchers are exploring the characteristics of dark energy through these theories, which involve adding or replacing curvature invariants in the Einstein-Hilbert action.

• Lovelock theory of gravity, a direct generalization of General Relativity in lower dimensions, and Gauss-Bonnet gravity, a higher-dimensional counterpart, are examples of modified gravity theories that have been studied for their implications on cosmic history.

• The Gauss-Bonnet invariant, a quadratic curvature term, is notable for its stability properties and its ability to avoid spin-2 ghost instabilities, making it a promising candidate for cosmological models.

• In @xmath0 gravity, the dynamics of the Gauss-Bonnet invariant can be explored by coupling it with a scalar field or adding a generic function to the Einstein-Hilbert action. These approaches have been used to discuss cosmological evolution and have been applied in string theory and cosmological models.

• The paper discusses the reconstruction and stability analysis of various cosmological models, including de Sitter and power-law solutions, within @xmath0 gravity. The stability of these models against linear perturbations is numerically analyzed, revealing that some models are stable while others are not.

• The paper concludes that cosmological reconstruction and stability analysis can restrict the applicability of @xmath0 gravity in the background of a Friedmann-Robertson-Walker universe. The stability analysis indicates that @xmath0 gravity may not fully explain the cosmic evolution of matter and radiation-dominated eras.

• The paper also explores the reconstruction of the @xmath0 model to describe both phantom and non-phantom cosmic histories. However, the reconstruction fails to reproduce the @xmath13CDM cosmology, suggesting that @xmath0 gravity may correspond to a CDM-dominated universe without a cosmological constant.

• The paper's findings contribute to the ongoing investigation of modified gravity theories and their potential to explain cosmic evolution, highlighting the importance of stability analysis in assessing the viability of these theories.

• Majorana fermions (MFs) are proposed as a means for decoherence-free quantum computation and information processing, with potential applications in topological superconductors.

• Experimental evidence for Majorana bound states (MBS) in condensed matter systems is challenging to obtain due to the difficulty in distinguishing MFS from other mechanisms like Kondo resonance and disorder effects.

• An all-optical scheme is proposed to detect MFs in iron chains on a superconducting pb surface, using a coupled quantum dot (QD)-nanomechanical resonator (NR) system with optical pump-probe technology.

• The QD-NR system is sensitive to the Majorana signature, which manifests as changes in the coherent optical spectrum of the QD, without direct contact with MFs.

• The scheme benefits from the high natural frequencies and large quality factors of NRs, enhancing the coherent optical properties and providing an ultrasensitive detection method.

• The QD is considered a two-level system, and the Majorana signature is carried through the coherent optical spectrum of the QD when coupled to MFs at the ends of iron chains.

• The optical detection scheme offers a new method for MF detection, different from the zero-bias peak in tunneling experiments, and can work for both coupled and uncoupled MF edge states.

• The role of the NR in the hybrid system is to enhance the exciton resonance spectrum, making MFs more detectable and sensitive to the NR's vibrations.

• The QD-NR system can be used to read out the exciton states of the QD, and the NR acts as a phonon cavity to amplify the exciton resonance spectrum.

• The proposed optical scheme provides a platform for applications in all-optically controlled topological quantum computing based on MFs.

• The authors acknowledge support from various foundations and the key foundation for young talents in Anhui province for their research.

• The optical detection scheme is the first all-optical means to probe MFs, utilizing quantum interference between the NR and the beat of two optical fields via the QD.
